metadata.titleEn: A multilayer daily gridded homogenized soil temperature dataset over continental China (1960-2017)
metadata.description: This dataset is the daily soil temperature data over continental China, with a spatial resolution of 0.25° at six soil depths (i.e., 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 40 cm), and a time range of 1960.01.01-2017.12.31. This dataset is generated through using multiple homogenization method to revise the inhomogenization of data, and using the statistical interpolation methods (i.e., the thin plate spline interpolation method and the angular distance weighting interpolation method) for gridded data processing, based on daily soil temperature data at more than 2400 meteorological stations across mainland of China. This dataset can well reflect the variation characteristics of soil temperature in China, and it can be used as the basic data in the field of future climate change research.
metadata.instructions: Data file naming method: Data files are titled as "HOM_TS0cm_daily_025x025_1960_2017. nc", including HOM_TS0cm said surface down 0 cm deep soil temperature homogenization lattice data, accordingly, 5 cm deep below the surface of data called "HOM_TS5cm_daily_025x025_1960_2017. nc", the surface of 10 cm deep down data called "HOM_TS10cm_daily_025x025_1960_2017. nc", and so on. Use method: the data stored in NETCDF format, can use NCL, Python and MATLAB programming languages to read, also can be visualized in the Panoply software.

background: Terrestrial soil contains huge heat, which supports food and energy for humans and land ecosystem survival. The soil heat content is also an important energy source affecting regional atmospheric circulation and climate change. Changes in soil heat storage have significant effects on many aspects of the earth system, such as climate, water, and ecology. As a conventional indicator of soil heat, soil temperature (TS) shows significant effects on the respiration of organic soil layers, which in turn influences the rate of organic carbon released into the atmosphere as CO2. TS also plays a pivotal role in the exchange of energy and water vapour between the atmosphere and land surface, and it can affect the partition of net radiation into sensible and latent heat fluxes, which will then influence the circulation in the atmospheric boundary layer. In addition, the impact of TS on local atmospheric processes may also propagate downstream through dynamic and thermodynamic processes and then influence the climate in remote regions. Moreover, many studies have shown that the antecedent TS in arid/semiarid regions of Northwest China can be one of the predictors of climate change in the Eastern Plain region. TS is one of the routinely measured quantities at meteorological stations. However, due to the complex terrain, human activities and severe weather conditions, the meteorological stations are not evenly distributed. In climate research, gridded products have a great attraction for data users due to their ease of use. These products include global data sets, such as GPCC (the Global Precipitation Climatology Center), CRU (the Climatic Research Unit), and regional data sets, such as the gauge-based daily precipitation data set over East Asia, APRODITE (the Asian Precipitation-Highly Resolved Observational Data), and CN05.1 (the daily meteorological data set over mainland China). In China, observations of TS at multiple soil depths have been available from more than 2,000 stations since 1960. Researchers have made great efforts to develop various methods for interpolating irregular station observations to uniform gridded data sets.
research objective: To conveniently use TS data set in climate researches, this study intends to convert the in-situ TS observations from irregularly distributed stations to rectangular grids.
challenges: Nonetheless, limited by the availability of reliable TS data, especially over vast regions for longer periods, the existing studies on TS and their conclusions are far from sufficient for a comprehensive understanding of its properties and role in climate change. Moreover, other objective factors, for example, the uneven distribution of stations, the timing discontinuity of observations caused by station migration and equipment damage, may also limit the use of observational TS records.
methods: First, at each station, the observed TS is split into a daily climatology of 1981–2010 and a daily anomaly for 1960–2017. Then, they are respectively interpolated to 0.25/C14 × 0.25/C14 horizontal resolution by using the thin-plain spline and the angular distance weight interpolation methods. Finally, a gridded multilayer TS data set is constructed from the sum of the above two gridded products. Latitude, longitude, and high-resolution digital elevation models are explicitly incorporated into the interpolation processes.
dataset: This paper describes the construction of a 0.25/C14 × 0.25/C14 daily soil temperature (TS) data set at six soil depths (i.e., 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 40 cm) based on a homogenized TS at more than 2,000 meteorological stations across mainland China for 1960–2017. In China, observations of TS at multiple soil depths have been available from more than 2,000 stations since 1960. We recently conducted a homogenized procedure to eliminate non-climate-inducing errors in this TS data set and obtained a homogenized long-term continuous TS data set at six soil depths at 2360 stations in China for 1960–2017.
findings: The results show that the gridded TS climatology is slightly lower than the station observations. The long-term gridded TS data not only preserves the spatial features represented in the station observations, but also provides a spatio-temporal continuous long-term product of mainland China. The gridded TS over the majority of land displays significantly positive trends in both summer and winter (p > 95%), indicating an overall warming land surface in China.

background: Land surface temperature (LST) is a fundamental parameter in the climate field that is indicative of the thermal radiance from the ground surface. It directly influences the sensible and latent heat fluxes from the land surface to the planetary boundary layer. Changes in LST and soil temperature can also be used as indicators of climate change. Furthermore, several researchers have considered the difference between LST and land surface air temperature (LSAT) as a teleconnection factor to predict changes in precipitation in downstream regions. Long-term instrumental LST data have been collected and stored for many decades in China. As one of the conventional observations, LST is liable to be influenced by changes in non-climatic factors (e.g., station migration, equipment replacement, and changes in the environment around the station location). If we keep such inhomogeneities and directly analyze the raw data, which may inaccurately describe actual climate variations, then we will potentially reach incorrect conclusions, particularly in the representation of long-term trends and extremes. Therefore, it is necessary to homogenize the raw observed LST before it can be used as the “ground truth” in various applications. To homogenize the LST dataset, several methods have been developed and applied in different countries. Previous studies have mainly focused on homogenizing LST datasets on monthly time scales. The daily LST can describe temporal variations at synoptic scales and is a needed parameter in weather forecasting as well as in modeling applications.
research objective: This study attempts to reduce the above biases in raw daily measurements and achieves a homogenized daily LST dataset over China using 2360 stations from 1960 through 2017.
challenges: Raw measured LSTs may contain biases due to instrument replacement, changes in recording procedures, and other non-climatic factors.
methods: The high-quality land surface air temperature (LSAT) dataset is used to correct the LST warming biases especially evident during cold months in regions north of 40ºN due to the replacement of observation instruments around 2004. Subsequently, the Multiple Analysis of Series for Homogenization (MASH) method is adopted to detect and then adjust the daily observed LST records.
dataset: This study attempts to reduce the above biases in raw daily measurements and achieves a homogenized daily LST dataset over China using 2360 stations from 1960 through 2017.
findings: Compared to the raw LST dataset over the whole domain, the homogenization significantly reduces the mean LST magnitude and its interannual variability as well as its linear trend at most stations. Finally, we perform preliminary analysis upon the homogenized LST and find that the annual mean LST averaged across China shows a significant warming trend [0.22ºC (10 yr)–1].

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that helps convert irregularly distributed soil temperature observations to uniform gridded data?
Example.Answer: One method involves splitting observed soil temperature (TS) at each station into a daily climatology and a daily anomaly. These are interpolated to a 0.25° × 0.25° horizontal resolution using thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods, followed by constructing a gridded multilayer TS dataset from the sum of these gridded products.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in creating a comprehensive soil temperature dataset and how is it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the uneven distribution of meteorological stations and timing discontinuity in observations due to station migration and equipment damage. This is addressed by applying a homogenization procedure to eliminate non-climate-inducing errors, thereby creating a consistent long-term dataset.

Example.Question: Provide an example of a technique used to address biases in land surface temperature datasets induced by non-climatic factors.
Example.Answer: To address biases, the Multiple Analysis of Series for Homogenization (MASH) method can be used to detect and adjust daily observed land surface temperature records, correcting biases such as those from instrument replacement or changes in recording procedures.

Definition.Question: What does 'homogenization' mean in the context of soil temperature datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of soil temperature datasets, 'homogenization' refers to the process of eliminating non-climate-inducing errors, such as those caused by station migration or equipment changes, to ensure that the data accurately represent true climate variations over time.

Definition.Question: What is the 'thin-plain spline interpolation method' as used in data collection for gridded soil temperature datasets?
Definition.Answer: The 'thin-plain spline interpolation method' is a technique used to interpolate irregularly distributed observational data onto a uniform grid. It is applied to convert in-situ soil temperature observations from meteorological stations into a gridded format by incorporating latitude, longitude, and elevation data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced during the creation of a homogenized soil temperature dataset compared to a homogenized land surface temperature dataset?
Comparison.Answer: The creation of a homogenized soil temperature dataset faces challenges such as uneven distribution of stations and timing discontinuity due to station migration. In contrast, the homogenized land surface temperature dataset deals with biases from instrument replacement and changes in recording procedures. Both datasets require homogenization to ensure accurate representation of long-term trends, yet the specific sources and types of biases addressed differ between them.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for addressing observation biases in soil temperature datasets compare to those used for land surface temperature datasets?
Comparison.Answer: In soil temperature datasets, observation biases are addressed by homogenizing data to eliminate non-climate-inducing errors and interpolating using specific methods like thin-plain spline. For land surface temperature datasets, biases are corrected using a high-quality LSAT dataset to adjust biases, particularly in colder months, followed by the MASH method for further homogenization. Both approaches aim to improve data reliability, but they use different reference datasets and bias correction techniques.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods affect the accuracy and reliability of soil temperature data collected for climate research?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of these interpolation methods allows for converting in-situ observations from irregularly distributed stations into a uniform gridded format. This helps in maintaining spatial features while providing a continuous long-term product, potentially enhancing the accuracy and reliability of data for climate research.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do changes in non-climatic factors, such as station migration and equipment replacement, pose to the collection and homogenization of land surface temperature data over long periods?
Interpretation.Answer: Non-climatic factors introduce biases in raw temperature measurements, which can obscure actual climate variations. These biases need to be corrected, as they can affect the representation of long-term trends and extremes, necessitating methods like homogenization to ensure data reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in converting irregularly distributed in-situ soil temperature observations to uniform gridded datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise due to the uneven distribution of meteorological stations, timing discontinuity of observations caused by station migration, and equipment damage, which limit the use of observational soil temperature records.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be limitations in the availability of reliable soil temperature data over vast regions and for longer periods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations are primarily due to the uneven station distribution, non-climate-inducing errors, and discontinuities in observations, which can hinder the comprehensive understanding of soil temperature's role in climate change.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to biases in raw daily land surface temperature measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Biases in raw daily land surface temperature measurements are caused by instrument replacement, changes in recording procedures, and other non-climatic factors that affect the accuracy of the data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does converting irregularly distributed station observations into gridded data affect the usability of soil temperature datasets in climate research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Converting irregularly distributed station observations into gridded data enhances usability by providing a spatio-temporal continuous long-term product that preserves spatial features and can be easily utilized in climate research, despite the challenges of uneven station distribution and timing discontinuities.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to convert in-situ soil temperature observations from irregularly distributed stations to rectangular grids in climate research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of converting in-situ soil temperature observations to rectangular grids is to facilitate the use of soil temperature data in climate research by providing a uniform and continuous data set that can overcome the challenges posed by irregular station distribution, non-climatic errors, and other observational biases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the development of a homogenized long-term land surface temperature dataset across China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of developing a homogenized long-term land surface temperature dataset is to reduce biases in raw daily measurements related to non-climatic factors such as instrument changes and station migration, thereby ensuring accurate climate variation analysis and improving the reliability of the data for various applications, including weather forecasting and climate modeling.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind using the thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods in constructing a gridded soil temperature dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale for using the thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods is to accurately interpolate daily climatology and anomalies from station data to a uniform grid, ensuring that the dataset reflects spatial features and provides a continuous long-term soil temperature product for climate research in mainland China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can observational soil temperature data from irregularly distributed meteorological stations be converted into uniform gridded datasets for climate research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The observational soil temperature data can be converted into uniform gridded datasets by splitting the observed data into a daily climatology and daily anomaly, which are then interpolated using thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods. Latitude, longitude, and high-resolution digital elevation models are incorporated into the interpolation process to construct a gridded multilayer soil temperature dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to homogenize raw daily land surface temperature data to mitigate biases introduced by non-climatic factors?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To homogenize raw daily land surface temperature data, the high-quality land surface air temperature dataset is used to correct warming biases, particularly those evident during cold months due to instrument replacement. The Multiple Analysis of Series for Homogenization (MASH) method is then adopted to detect and adjust biases in the daily observed land surface temperature records.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods used to address the challenges of uneven station distribution and data discontinuities in long-term soil temperature datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address uneven station distribution and data discontinuities, methods such as homogenizing procedures are conducted to eliminate non-climate-inducing errors, and interpolation techniques like thin-plain spline and angular distance weight methods are used to convert station observations into gridded datasets. These approaches help create a long-term continuous soil temperature dataset that maintains spatial features while being spatio-temporally comprehensive.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the conversion of irregularly distributed soil temperature observations into uniformly gridded datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The conversion is achieved by splitting the observed soil temperature into a daily climatology and a daily anomaly. These are then interpolated to a 0.25° × 0.25° horizontal resolution using thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods, incorporating latitude, longitude, and digital elevation models.

Enablement.Question: How do homogenization techniques enable the use of land surface temperature data in long-term climate studies?
Enablement.Answer: Homogenization techniques, such as the Multiple Analysis of Series for Homogenization (MASH) method, correct biases in raw measured land surface temperatures caused by instrument replacement and other non-climatic factors. This process results in a more accurate representation of climate variations and trends, thus enabling reliable long-term climate studies.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitate the development of gridded soil temperature datasets that reflect spatial and temporal changes across vast regions?
Enablement.Answer: Gridded soil temperature datasets are facilitated by the availability of long-term, multi-depth observations from numerous meteorological stations. The application of homogenization procedures to eliminate non-climatic errors and the use of interpolation methods to convert station data into gridded formats are crucial conditions for their development.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for soil temperature observations face challenges in achieving uniform station distribution?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection methods for soil temperature observations might face challenges due to complex terrain, human activities, and severe weather conditions, which can result in meteorological stations being unevenly distributed.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to apply homogenization procedures to land surface temperature datasets before using them in climate research?
Expectation.Answer: It is necessary to apply homogenization procedures to land surface temperature datasets to correct biases resulting from non-climatic factors such as station migration, equipment replacement, and environmental changes around station locations, ensuring that the data accurately reflects actual climate variations.

Expectation.Question: What might be the reasons for using interpolation methods when converting in-situ soil temperature observations to gridded datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Interpolation methods are used to convert in-situ soil temperature observations to gridded datasets to address the uneven distribution of observation stations and to create a spatio-temporal continuous long-term product that preserves the spatial features of the original data.

Judgmental.Question: How might the interpolation methods used in creating gridded soil temperature datasets affect the accuracy and reliability of the resulting data?
Judgmental.Answer: The interpolation methods, such as thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation, are crucial for transforming irregularly distributed station observations into uniform gridded data. These methods are carefully chosen to maintain spatial features and provide a continuous product. However, the accuracy and reliability could be influenced by factors like the uneven distribution of stations and timing discontinuities in observations, which may introduce biases if not properly accounted for.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges associated with ensuring the homogenization of long-term soil temperature datasets, and how do these challenges impact the quality of the data?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in homogenizing soil temperature datasets include biases from instrument replacement, changes in recording procedures, and non-climatic factors. These issues can lead to inaccurate climate variation descriptions if not addressed. Homogenization methods are employed to correct these biases, thus enhancing the dataset's quality by reducing mean magnitude, interannual variability, and linear trends, especially evident during instrument changes around 2004.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the development of gridded soil temperature datasets contribute to climate change research, particularly in regions with complex terrain and uneven station distribution?
Judgmental.Answer: Gridded soil temperature datasets facilitate climate change research by providing spatially continuous and temporally long-term data, which are especially valuable in regions with complex terrain and uneven station distribution. These datasets preserve spatial features and trends, such as warming land surfaces, and enable easier use in climate models, helping researchers to better understand the impacts of soil temperature on atmospheric processes and climate patterns.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how irregularly distributed soil temperature observations can be transformed into a uniform grid for analysis.
Assertion.Answer: The observed soil temperature (TS) data at each station is split into a daily climatology and a daily anomaly, which are then interpolated to a uniform grid using thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods, incorporating latitude, longitude, and digital elevation models in the process.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges involved in maintaining long-term continuity and consistency in soil temperature datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the uneven distribution of meteorological stations, timing discontinuity of observations due to station migration and equipment damage, and biases introduced by non-climatic factors such as station relocation and instrument replacement.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the significance of using homogenized datasets in climate research related to soil and land surface temperatures.
Assertion.Answer: Homogenized datasets are crucial as they eliminate non-climatic errors, providing a consistent and reliable basis for analyzing long-term trends and changes in soil and land surface temperatures, which are vital for understanding impacts on regional atmospheric circulation, climate change, and ecological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used in converting in-situ soil temperature observations from irregularly distributed stations to a uniform gridded format.
Request/Directive.Answer: The conversion of in-situ soil temperature observations to a gridded format involves splitting the observed data into a daily climatology and a daily anomaly. These are then interpolated using thin-plain spline and angular distance weight interpolation methods to achieve a 0.25° × 0.25° horizontal resolution. Latitude, longitude, and high-resolution digital elevation models are incorporated into the interpolation processes to construct a multilayer soil temperature dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges faced in collecting and utilizing soil temperature data over extended periods and vast regions, and suggest methods to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting soil temperature data include the uneven distribution of stations, timing discontinuity of observations due to station migration and equipment damage, and the availability of reliable data over extensive regions and periods. To address these challenges, a homogenization procedure is applied to eliminate non-climate-induced errors, and advanced interpolation methods are used to create a continuous and reliable gridded dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the techniques used to homogenize land surface temperature data and reduce biases from instrumentation changes and other non-climatic factors.
Request/Directive.Answer: To homogenize land surface temperature data, a high-quality land surface air temperature dataset is used to correct warming biases, particularly those evident in cold months due to instrument replacement. The Multiple Analysis of Series for Homogenization (MASH) method is then adopted to detect and adjust daily observed records, significantly reducing the mean magnitude, interannual variability, and linear trends of the land surface temperature dataset.
